description: From Middle English taxe, from Middle French taxe, from Medieval Latin taxa. Doublet of task. Displaced native Old English gafol, which was also the word for "tribute" and "rent."

entries.meaning: Money paid to the government other than for transaction-specific goods and services.
examples: Synonyms: impost, tribute, contribution, duty, toll, rate, assessment, exaction, custom, demand, levy
a heavy tax on time or health

entries.meaning: A task exacted from one who is under control; a contribution or service, the rendering of which is imposed upon a subject.

description: From Middle English taxen, from Anglo-Norman taxer (“to impose a tax”), from Latin taxāre, present active infinitive of taxō (“I handle”, “I censure”, “I appraise”, “I compute”).

verbs.description: tax (third-person singular simple present taxes, present participle taxing, simple past and past participle taxed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impose and collect a tax from (a person or company).
examples: Some think to tax the wealthy is the fairest.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impose and collect a tax on (something).
examples: Some think to tax wealth is destructive of a private sector.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To examine accounts in order to allow or disallow items.
